School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description: In order to understand and evaluate risk and uncertainty it is essential to have a strong command of basic statistical concepts and techniques. This course is designed to furnish students with the fundamental tools of statistical analysis, including analysis of descriptive statistics, probability distributions, statistical inference and related tests, correlation and conditional expectation.  In addition to providing familiarity with statistical principles, the course will also include an introduction to basic statistical software packages, namely STATA and advanced tools in Excel.  It is a required course for quantitative approaches to risk assessment.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description: This workshop is designed to strengthen students' writing skills with an eye to improving academic performance and preparing for subsequent professional challenges. The course focuses on academic and professional writing with an emphasis on European public policy. Students will complete short readings and participate in inter-active lectures and discussion. They will also have the opportunity to do practical exercises in and outside of class. Students will acquire fundamental tools to plan, write and edit an effective briefing and motivational letter. In particular, they will learn how to identify the implications of an issue; create a logical structure of ideas; elaborate and support ideas; and produce precise, concise, and cohesive prose.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description: The course provides students with the opportunity to hone and refine their listening and speaking skills before the semester begins. Listening comprehension is developed through audios and videos of academic presentations. Speaking skills will be practiced through discussions, debates, and formal presentations. Vocabulary specific to SAIS-related disciplines (politics, history, energy, economics, development, etc.) is of prime importance. The acquisition of high-level academic vocabulary is emphasized, as is the correct use of advanced grammar, syntax, and usage points. Advanced grammar points are reviewed as the need arises. As the course is student-centered, the class progress depends largely on interactive dynamics of participation and collaboration. Students who meet all the requirements and pass the course will receive either a "HP" (high pass) or "P" (pass) on their transcript.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description:
This intensive, four-week preterm course is designed to provide graduate students with an opportunity to hone their academic writing and reading skills in preparation for their first semester at SAIS. Students will develop these skills via a range of synchronous and asynchronous activities that closely mirror the tasks they’ll undertake in their Fall courses. During the live group seminars and workshops held regularly each week, the instructor will i) develop students’ understanding of specific essay typologies; ii) help students improve their hold over grammatical and syntactical accuracy via textual editing tasks, and iii) lead students in a discussion of the required readings. The individual writing consultations, held each week, will provide students with the opportunity to review their language challenges directly with the writing instructor.  
This online course will be hosted on the Canvas teaching platform.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description:
Intensive Italian is a one hundred-hour in-person course for beginners. In addition to providing a linguistic and cultural foundation for daily life and linguistic autonomy in Bologna, the Intensive Italian course is the perfect tool for those who wish to continue studying Italian. This course offers a solid communicative, functional, lexical, and grammatical foundation, from which students can further enrich their linguistic competence in Italian.

Methodology and Teaching Techniques
The focus of Intensive Italian is twofold: communication and formal correctness with an awareness of linguistic accuracy. Being a course taught with a notional-functional method, Intensive Italian enables students to "do things with the language" while also understanding the linguistic mechanisms underlying individual communicative acts. Peer work, project-based learning, and accurate linguistic and metalinguistic reflections are the strengths of the Intensive course. Learning takes place through informal and autonomous activities, but with continuous support from the instructor and moments of formal reflection on the language mechanisms.
Depending on individual motivation, commitment, experience, and language background, the course should enable students to achieve levels between A1 (Breakthrough) and A2 (Waystage) of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) or Novice High to Intermediate Mid levels of the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) Framework.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description:
Survival Italian is an intensive, fifty-hour, in-person course for beginners. The objective of the course is  to provide an initial linguistic and cultural foundation in Italian to begin building one's autonomy in Bologna, and for those wishing to continue studying Italian in the Fall, to lay the first foundation in their journey of acquiring the Italian language. For these reasons, the course provides students with elementary vocabulary, key structures, and basic grammatical rules in a steady, progressive, direct, and lively fashion.

Methodology and Teaching Techniques
The focus of Survival Italian is undoubtedly communication: from the first day, the course lessons are conducted in Italian. Efforts are made to avoid, as much as possible, reference to and translation from English, as well as the mechanical study of grammar during the lessons. The method aims to help students think in Italian from the outset and to understand and deduce the rules rather than simply applying them. Metalinguistic analysis does not play a central role in the course. Peer work and project-based learning are two strengths of the Survival course: learning takes place through informal and autonomous activities, but with continuous support from the instructor. Depending on individual motivation, commitment, experience, and language background, the course should allow students to reach between the A1 (Breakthrough) and A2 (Waystage) levels of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) or the Novice High to Intermediate Mid levels of the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) Framework.
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies

Course Description: This course is designed to furnish students with the fundamental tools of statistical analysis, including analysis of descriptive statistics, probability distributions, statistical inference and related tests, correlation and conditional expectation. The aim of the course is to introduce the basic statistical tools required to conduct and evaluate empirical research in economics and the social sciences. Special attention will be given to the application of these statistical tools to the analysis of real phenomena. This course is a prerequisite for more advanced courses in econometrics and fulfills a Data Analytics requirement for the MAIR degree.
Department: ['SA Data Analytics', 'SA International Economics and Finance', 'SB International Economics']
School: Nitze School of Advanced International Studies
